title: Merlin
description: Merlin is an implementation of Polygon CDK chain. It looks to build a validia chain using an alternative system for data availability. It will be leveraging the Bsquared Network parent blockchain for settlement. Its documentation shares that it will add Bitcoin native security in the future, but no code or research has been released.

riskAnalysis.title: Information on multi-sig signers not available
riskAnalysis.content: We are currently reviewing the bridge program related to Merlin. Due to there being no information signers of the multi-sig custodying users' funds, we classify the bridge program as high risk. The vault that mints BTC on Merlin is an upgradeable contract.

riskAnalysis.title: Uses a DAC for offchain data availability. Members under review
riskAnalysis.content: Merlin chain is built on the Polygon CDK stack. In its Github, it has a copy of the Polygon CDK Committee contract. In the contract, it states that the admin has the control to set up the committee, so it is likely that the members of this committee are permissioned and selected by the Merlin Chain operator.

riskAnalysis.title: Blocks are produced by a centralized sequencer
riskAnalysis.content: Merlin chain blocks are currently produced by a centralized sequencer.

riskAnalysis.title: zkSNARKs ensure state correctness, but no settlement guarantees inherited from Bitcoin
riskAnalysis.content: Merlin uses zkSNARKS to ensure state correctness. The Merlin prover posts validity proofs of execution to its L1 contract to finalize state transitions. It is unknown which chain Merlin settles to. Its documentation previously pointed to Ethereum, but recent contracts cannot be verified on Ethereum.

content.title: Merlin L1 smart contract not verified
content.content: We are currenly unable to verify if the smart contracts listed in Merlin's Github are in fact the contracts used on its mainnet. The main contract for Polygoin CDKValidium on Ethereum was previously listed as the Merlin L1 contract in its documentation, but that contract was removed and no longer listed. Merlin chain have announced they will deploy their chain on Bsquared Network's L1 blockchain, which is a permissioned fork of Ethermint. New contracts have been listed in its Github, but their L1 RPC points to a different chain that is not Bsquared Network.

content.title: All facets of Merlin chain are managed by a centralized operator. Some code is not open-source.
content.content: Merlin Chain contracts are all currently upgradeable by an admin. The contracts it has listed on its CDKValdidium can not be verified. It is likely that Merlin Chain is running their own permissioned fork for their L1 blockchain. Because we cannot verify the L1 blockchain Merlin Chain is currently settling to, we have listed it as a testnet implementation and a high risk chain for depositing funds.
